Where applicable this is the transport layer protocol port range an IPv4-based or IPv6-based service uses.

To be validated as a natural number (integer \>= 1). A single port uses the same value for start and end. Use multiple 'port-range' entries for non-contiguous ranges.

AssemblyOscalImplementationCommonSystemC.title: Component
AssemblyOscalImplementationCommonSystemC.description:
A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.

Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies, processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security and/or privacy.

The `type` indicates which of these component types is represented.

When defining a `service` component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more `link` entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.

uuid.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this component elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `component` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

type.description: A category describing the purpose of the component.

title.title: Component Title
title.description: A human readable name for the system component.

description.title: Component Description
description.description: A description of the component, including information about its function.

purpose.title: Purpose
purpose.description: A summary of the technological or business purpose of the component.

system.title: Action Type System
system.description:
Specifies the action type system used.

Provides a means to segment the value space for the `type`, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed `action`'s `type`. This allows the semantics associated with a given `type` to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.

An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.

AssemblyOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceR.title: Resource link
AssemblyOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceR.description:
A URL-based pointer to an external resource with an optional hash for verification and change detection.

Multiple `rlink` objects can be included for a resource. In such a case, all provided `rlink` items are intended to be equivalent in content, but may differ in structure or format.

A `media-type` is used to identify the format of a given rlink, and can be used to differentiate items in a collection of rlinks. The `media-type` provides a hint to the OSCAL document consumer about the structure of the resource referenced by the `rlink`.

href.title: Hypertext Reference
href.description:
A resolvable URL pointing to the referenced resource.

This value may be either:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or

media-type.title: Media Type
media-type.description: A label that indicates the nature of a resource, as a data serialization or format.

hashes.title: Hash
hashes.description:
A hash of the resource identified by `href`, which can be used to verify the resource was not changed since it was hashed.

The `hash` value can be used to confirm that the resource referenced by the `href` is the same resources that was hashed by retrieving the resource, calculating a hash, and comparing the result to this value.

AssemblyOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceT.title: Resource
AssemblyOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceT.description:
A resource associated with content in the containing document instance. A resource may be directly included in the document using base64 encoding or may point to one or more equivalent internet resources.

A resource can be used in two ways. 1) it may point to an specific retrievable network resource using a `rlink`, or 2) it may be included as an attachment using a `base64`. A resource may contain multiple `rlink` and `base64` entries that represent alternative download locations (rlink) and attachments (base64) for the same resource.

Both rlink and base64 allow for a `media-type` to be specified, which is used to distinguish between different representations of the same resource (e.g., Microsoft Word, PDF). When multiple `rlink` and `base64` items are included for a given resource, all items must contain equivalent information. This allows the document consumer to choose a preferred item to process based on a the selected item's `media-type`. This is extremely important when the items represent OSCAL content that is represented in alternate formats (i.e., XML, JSON, YAML), allowing the same OSCAL data to be processed from any of the available formats indicated by the items.

When a resource includes a citation, then the `title` and `citation` properties must both be included.

uuid.title: Resource Universally Unique Identifier
uuid.description: A unique identifier for a resource.

title.title: Resource Title
title.description: An optional name given to the resource, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

description.title: Resource Description
description.description: An optional short summary of the resource used to indicate the purpose of the resource.

props.description: An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair.

document-ids.title: Document Identifier
document-ids.description: A document identifier qualified by an identifier `scheme`.

citation.title: Citation
citation.description: An optional citation consisting of end note text using structured markup.

rlinks.title: Resource link
rlinks.description:
A URL-based pointer to an external resource with an optional hash for verification and change detection.

Multiple `rlink` objects can be included for a resource. In such a case, all provided `rlink` items are intended to be equivalent in content, but may differ in structure or format.

A `media-type` is used to identify the format of a given rlink, and can be used to differentiate items in a collection of rlinks. The `media-type` provides a hint to the OSCAL document consumer about the structure of the resource referenced by the `rlink`.

base64.title: Base64
base64.description: A resource encoded using the Base64 alphabet defined by [RFC 2045](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2045.html).

remarks.description: Additional commentary about the containing object.

AssemblyOscalMetadataBackMatterType.title: Back matter
AssemblyOscalMetadataBackMatterType.description:
A collection of resources that may be referenced from within the OSCAL document instance.

Provides a collection of identified `resource` objects that can be referenced by a `link` with a `rel` value of "reference" and an `href` value that is a fragment "#" followed by a reference to a reference's `uuid`. Other specialized link "rel" values also use this pattern when indicated in that context of use.

resources.title: Resource
resources.description:
A resource associated with content in the containing document instance. A resource may be directly included in the document using base64 encoding or may point to one or more equivalent internet resources.

A resource can be used in two ways. 1) it may point to an specific retrievable network resource using a `rlink`, or 2) it may be included as an attachment using a `base64`. A resource may contain multiple `rlink` and `base64` entries that represent alternative download locations (rlink) and attachments (base64) for the same resource.

Both rlink and base64 allow for a `media-type` to be specified, which is used to distinguish between different representations of the same resource (e.g., Microsoft Word, PDF). When multiple `rlink` and `base64` items are included for a given resource, all items must contain equivalent information. This allows the document consumer to choose a preferred item to process based on a the selected item's `media-type`. This is extremely important when the items represent OSCAL content that is represented in alternate formats (i.e., XML, JSON, YAML), allowing the same OSCAL data to be processed from any of the available formats indicated by the items.

When a resource includes a citation, then the `title` and `citation` properties must both be included.

AssemblyOscalMetadataLinkType.title: Link
AssemblyOscalMetadataLinkType.description:
A reference to a local or remote resource, that has a specific relation to the containing object.

To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to a back matter `resource` is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the `rlink/hash` object.

The OSCAL `link` is a roughly based on the HTML [link element](https://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/links.html#edef-LINK).

href.title: Hypertext Reference
href.description:
A resolvable URL reference to a resource.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to an OSCAL object by the objects identifier (e.g., id, uuid) in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)). The specific object type will differ based on the link relationship type.

rel.title: Link Relation Type
rel.description: Describes the type of relationship provided by the link's hypertext reference. This can be an indicator of the link's purpose.

media-type.title: Link Media Type
media-type.description:
A label that indicates the nature of a resource, as a data serialization or format.

The `media-type` provides a hint about the content model of the referenced resource. A valid entry from the [IANA Media Types registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml) SHOULD be used.

resource-fragment.title: Resource Fragment
resource-fragment.description: In case where the `href` points to a `back-matter/resource`, this value will indicate the URI [fragment](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.5) to append to any `rlink` associated with the resource. This value MUST be [URI encoded](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.1).

text.title: Link Text
text.description: A textual label to associate with the link, which may be used for presentation in a tool.

AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataLocationTyp.title: Location
AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataLocationTyp.description:
A physical point of presence, which may be associated with people, organizations, or other concepts within the current or linked OSCAL document.

An address might be sensitive in nature. In such cases a title, mailing address, email-address, and/or phone number may be used instead.

uuid.title: Location Universally Unique Identifier
uuid.description: A unique ID for the location, for reference.

title.title: Location Title
title.description: A name given to the location, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

address.title: Address
address.description:
A postal address for the location.

The physical address of the location, which will provided for physical locations. Virtual locations can omit this data item.

email-addresses.title: Email Address
email-addresses.description:
An email address as defined by [RFC 5322 Section 3.4.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4.1).

A contact email associated with the location.

telephone-numbers.title: Telephone Number
telephone-numbers.description:
A telephone service number as defined by [ITU-T E.164](https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-E.164-201011-I/en).

A phone number used to contact the location.

urls.title: Location URL
urls.description:
The uniform resource locator (URL) for a web site or other resource associated with the location.

This data field is deprecated in favor of using a link with an appropriate relationship.

AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataPartyType.description:

A party can be optionally associated with either an address or a location. While providing a meaningful location for a party is desired, there are some cases where it might not be possible to provide an exact location or even any location.

member-of-organizations.title: Organizational Affiliation
member-of-organizations.description:
A reference to another `party` by UUID, typically an organization, that this subject is associated with.

Since the reference target of an organizational affiliation must be another `party` (whether further qualified as person or organization) as inidcated by its `uuid`. As a [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier with uniqueness across document and trans-document scope, this `uuid` value is sufficient to reference the data item locally or globally across related documents, e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance.

Parties of both the `person` or `organization` type can be associated with an organization using the `member-of-organization`.

AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataRevisionTyp.title: Revision History Entry
AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataRevisionTyp.description:
An entry in a sequential list of revisions to the containing document, expected to be in reverse chronological order (i.e. latest first).

While `published`, `last-modified`, and `oscal-version` are not required, values for these entries should be provided if the information is known. A `link` with a `rel` of "source" should be provided if the information is known.

title.title: Document Title
title.description: A name given to the document revision, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

published.title: Publication Timestamp
published.description: The date and time the document was last made available.

last-modified.title: Last Modified Timestamp
last-modified.description: The date and time the document was last stored for later retrieval.

version.title: Document Version
version.description: Used to distinguish a specific revision of an OSCAL document from other previous and future versions.

oscal-version.title: OSCAL Version
oscal-version.description: The OSCAL model version the document was authored against and will conform to as valid.

AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataRoleType.title: Role
AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataRoleType.description:
Defines a function, which might be assigned to a party in a specific situation.

Permissible values to be determined closer to the application (e.g. by a receiving authority).

OSCAL has defined a set of standardized roles for consistent use in OSCAL documents. This allows tools consuming OSCAL content to infer specific semantics when these roles are used. These roles are documented in the specific contexts of their use (e.g., responsible-party, responsible-role). When using such a role, it is necessary to define these roles in this list, which will then allow such a role to be referenced.

description.title: Role Description

AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataType.title: Document Metadata
AssemblyOscalMetadataMetadataType.description:
Provides information about the containing document, and defines concepts that are shared across the document.

All OSCAL documents use the same metadata structure, that provides a consistent way of expressing OSCAL document metadata across all OSCAL models. The metadata section also includes declarations of individual objects (i.e., roles, location, parties) that may be referenced within and across linked OSCAL documents.

The metadata in an OSCAL document has few required fields, representing only the bare minimum data needed to differentiate one instance from another. Tools and users creating OSCAL documents may choose to use any of the optional fields, as well as extension mechanisms (e.g., properties, links) to go beyond this minimum to suit their use cases.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use the `published`, `last-modified`, and `version` fields to establish information about an individual in a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for a previous revision can be represented as a `revision` within this object. Links may also be provided using the `predecessor-version` and `successor-version` link relations to provide for direct access to the related resource. These relations can be provided as a link child of this object or as `link` within a given `revision`.

A `responsible-party` entry in this context refers to roles and parties that have responsibility relative to the production, review, publication, and use of the containing document.

title.title: Document Title
title.description: A name given to the document, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

published.title: Publication Timestamp
published.description: The date and time the document was last made available.

last-modified.title: Last Modified Timestamp
last-modified.description: The date and time the document was last stored for later retrieval.

version.title: Document Version
version.description: Used to distinguish a specific revision of an OSCAL document from other previous and future versions.

oscal-version.title: OSCAL Version
oscal-version.description: The OSCAL model version the document was authored against and will conform to as valid.

revisions.title: Revision History Entry
revisions.description:
An entry in a sequential list of revisions to the containing document, expected to be in reverse chronological order (i.e. latest first).

While `published`, `last-modified`, and `oscal-version` are not required, values for these entries should be provided if the information is known. A `link` with a `rel` of "source" should be provided if the information is known.

document-ids.title: Document Identifier
document-ids.description: A document identifier qualified by an identifier `scheme`.

props.description: An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair.

links.title: Link
links.description: A reference to a local or remote resource, that has a specific relation to the containing object.

roles.title: Role
roles.description:
Defines a function, which might be assigned to a party in a specific situation.

Permissible values to be determined closer to the application (e.g. by a receiving authority).

OSCAL has defined a set of standardized roles for consistent use in OSCAL documents. This allows tools consuming OSCAL content to infer specific semantics when these roles are used. These roles are documented in the specific contexts of their use (e.g., responsible-party, responsible-role). When using such a role, it is necessary to define these roles in this list, which will then allow such a role to be referenced.

locations.title: Location
locations.description:
A physical point of presence, which may be associated with people, organizations, or other concepts within the current or linked OSCAL document.

An address might be sensitive in nature. In such cases a title, mailing address, email-address, and/or phone number may be used instead.

parties.title: Party
parties.description:
An organization or person, which may be associated with roles or other concepts within the current or linked OSCAL document.

A party can be optionally associated with either an address or a location. While providing a meaningful location for a party is desired, there are some cases where it might not be possible to provide an exact location or even any location.

responsible-parties.title: Responsible Party
responsible-parties.description: A reference to a set of persons and/or organizations that have responsibility for performing the referenced role in the context of the containing object.

actions.title: Action
actions.description: An action applied by a role within a given party to the content.

remarks.title: Remarks
remarks.description: Additional commentary about the containing object.

AssemblyOscalMetadataPropertyType.title: Property
AssemblyOscalMetadataPropertyType.description:
An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair.

Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order, and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure consistency.

Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context of the containing object.

name.title: Property Name
name.description: A textual label, within a namespace, that identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the property's containing object.

uuid.title: Property Universally Unique Identifier
uuid.description: A unique identifier for a property.

ns.title: Property Namespace
ns.description:
A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

When a `ns` is not provided, its value should be assumed to be `http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal` and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.

value.title: Property Value
value.description: Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.

class.title: Property Class
class.description:
A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's `name`.

This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same `name` and `ns`, or to group properties into categories.

A `class` can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a specific `class` value. It is available for grouping, but unlike `group` is not expected specifically to designate any group membership as such.

group.title: Property Group
group.description:
An identifier for relating distinct sets of properties.

Different sets of properties may relate to separate contexts. Declare a group on a property to associate it with one or more other properties in a given context.

remarks.title: Remarks
remarks.description: Additional commentary about the containing object.

AssemblyOscalMetadataResponsiblePartyTyp.title: Responsible Party
AssemblyOscalMetadataResponsiblePartyTyp.description:
A reference to a set of persons and/or organizations that have responsibility for performing the referenced role in the context of the containing object.

A `responsible-party` requires one or more `party-uuid` references creating a strong relationship arc between the referenced `role-id` and the reference parties. This differs in semantics from `responsible-role` which doesn't require that a `party-uuid` is referenced.

The scope of use of this object determines if the responsibility has been performed or will be performed in the future. The containing object will describe the intent.

role-id.title: Responsible Role
role-id.description: A reference to a `role` performed by a `party`.

party-uuids.title: Party Universally Unique Identifier Reference
party-uuids.description: Specifies one or more parties responsible for performing the associated `role`.

A reference to a role with responsibility for performing a function relative to the containing object, optionally associated with a set of persons and/or organizations that perform that role.

A `responsible-role` allows zero or more `party-uuid` references, each of which creates a relationship arc between the referenced `role-id` and the referenced party. This differs in semantics from `responsible-party`, which requires that at least one `party-uuid` is referenced.

The scope of use of this object determines if the responsibility has been performed or will be performed in the future. The containing object will describe the intent.

role-id.description: A [human-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#human-oriented) identifier reference to a `role` performed.

AssemblyOscalSspByComponentType.title: Component Control Implementation
AssemblyOscalSspByComponentType.description:
Defines how the referenced component implements a set of controls.

Use of `set-parameter` in this context, sets the parameter for the control referenced in the containing `implemented-requirement` applied to the referenced component. If the `by-component` is used as a child of a `statement`, then the parameter value also applies only in the context of the referenced statement. If the same parameter is also set in the `control-implementation` or a specific `implemented-requirement`, then this `by-component/set-parameter` value will override the other value(s) in the context of the referenced component, control, and statement (if parent).

The locally defined *UUID* of the `by-component` entry can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). AssemblyOscalSspImportProfileType.description: Used to import the OSCAL profile representing the system's control baseline.

href.title: Profile Reference
href.description:
A resolvable URL reference to the profile or catalog to use as the system's control baseline.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to a `back-matter` resource in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)).

If the resource is an OSCAL profile, it is expected that a tool will resolve the profile according to the OSCAL [profile resolution specification](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/processing/profile-resolution/) to produce a resolved profile for use when processing the containing system security plan. This allows a system security plan processor to use the baseline as a catalog of controls.

While it is possible to reference a previously resolved OSCAL profile as a catalog, this practice is discouraged since the unresolved form of the profile communicates more information about selections and changes to the underlying catalog. Furthermore, the underlying catalog can be maintained separately from the profile, which also has maintenance advantages for distinct maintainers, ensuring that the best available information is produced through profile resolution.

FieldOscalMetadataDocumentIdType.title: Document Identifier
FieldOscalMetadataDocumentIdType.description:
A document identifier qualified by an identifier `scheme`.

A document identifier provides a [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with a [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that is used for a group of documents that are to be treated as different versions, representations or digital surrogates of the same document.

A document identifier provides an additional data point for identifying a document that can be assigned by a publisher or organization for purposes in a wider system, such as a digital object identifier (DOI) or a local content management system identifier.

Use of a document identifier allows for document creators to associate sets of documents that are related in some way by the same `document-id`.

An OSCAL document always has an implicit document identifier provided by the document's UUID, defined by the `uuid` on the top-level object. Having a default UUID-based identifier ensures all documents can be minimally identified when other document identifiers are not provided.

scheme.title: Document Identification Scheme
scheme.description:
Qualifies the kind of document identifier using a URI. If the scheme is not provided the value of the element will be interpreted as a string of characters.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

FieldOscalMetadataEmailAddressType.title: Email Address
FieldOscalMetadataEmailAddressType.description: An email address as defined by [RFC 5322 Section 3.4.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4.1).

FieldOscalMetadataHashType.title: Hash
FieldOscalMetadataHashType.description: A representation of a cryptographic digest generated over a resource using a specified hash algorithm.

algorithm.title: Hash algorithm
algorithm.description:
The digest method by which a hash is derived.

Any other value used MUST be a value defined in the W3C [XML Security Algorithm Cross-Reference](https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlsec-algorithms/#digest-method-uris) Digest Methods (W3C, April 2013) or [RFC 6931 Section 2.1.5](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6931#section-2.1.5) New SHA Functions.

FieldOscalMetadataLastModifiedType.title: Last Modified Timestamp
FieldOscalMetadataLastModifiedType.description:
The date and time the document was last stored for later retrieval.

This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was last updated, or at the point of creation the creation date. Typically, this date value will be machine generated at time of creation or modification. Ideally, this field will be managed by the editing tool or service used to make modifications when storing the modified document.

The intent of the last modified timestamp is to distinguish between significant change milestones when the document may be accessed by multiple entities. This allows a given entity to differentiate between mutiple document states at specific points in time. It is possible to make multiple modifications to the document without storing these changes. In such a case, the last modified timestamp might not be updated until the document is finally stored.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the `last-modified` value should indicate the last modification time of the OSCAL document instance, not the source material.

FieldOscalMetadataMetadataPartyMemberOfO.title: Organizational Affiliation
FieldOscalMetadataMetadataPartyMemberOfO.description:
A reference to another `party` by UUID, typically an organization, that this subject is associated with.

Since the reference target of an organizational affiliation must be another `party` (whether further qualified as person or organization) as inidcated by its `uuid`. As a [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier with uniqueness across document and trans-document scope, this `uuid` value is sufficient to reference the data item locally or globally across related documents, e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance.

Parties of both the `person` or `organization` type can be associated with an organization using the `member-of-organization`.

FieldOscalMetadataOscalVersionType.title: OSCAL Version
FieldOscalMetadataOscalVersionType.description:
The OSCAL model version the document was authored against and will conform to as valid.

Indicates the version of the OSCAL model to which the document conforms, for example "1.1.0" or "1.0.0-milestone1". That can be used as a hint for a tool indicating which version of the OSCAL XML or JSON schema to use for validation.

The OSCAL version serves a different purpose from the document version and is used to represent a different concept. If both have the same value, this is coincidental.

FieldOscalMetadataPartyUuidType.title: Party Universally Unique Identifier Reference
FieldOscalMetadataPartyUuidType.description: Reference to a party by UUID.

FieldOscalMetadataPublishedType.title: Publication Timestamp
FieldOscalMetadataPublishedType.description:
The date and time the document was last made available.

Typically, this date value will be machine-generated at the time the containing document is published.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material provided in a different format. In such a case, the `published` value should indicate when the OSCAL document instance was last published, not the source material.

FieldOscalMetadataRemarksType.title: Remarks
FieldOscalMetadataRemarksType.description:
Additional commentary about the containing object.

The `remarks` field SHOULD not be used to store arbitrary data. Instead, a `prop` or `link` should be used to annotate or reference any additional data not formally supported by OSCAL.

FieldOscalMetadataRoleIdType.title: Role Identifier Reference
FieldOscalMetadataRoleIdType.description: Reference to a role by UUID.

FieldOscalMetadataTelephoneNumberType.title: Telephone Number
FieldOscalMetadataTelephoneNumberType.description: A telephone service number as defined by [ITU-T E.164](https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-E.164-201011-I/en).

type.title: type flag
type.description: Indicates the type of phone number.

FieldOscalMetadataVersionType.title: Document Version
FieldOscalMetadataVersionType.description:
Used to distinguish a specific revision of an OSCAL document from other previous and future versions.

A version may be a release number, sequence number, date, or other identifier sufficient to distinguish between different document revisions.

While not required, it is recommended that OSCAL content authors use [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html) as the version format. This allows for the easy identification of a version tree consisting of major, minor, and patch numbers.

A version is typically set by the document owner or by the tool used to maintain the content.

FieldOscalSspAdjustmentJustificationType.title: Adjustment Justification
FieldOscalSspAdjustmentJustificationType.description: If the selected security level is different from the base security level, this contains the justification for the change.

FieldOscalSspAuthorizationBoundaryDescri.title: Authorization Boundary Description
FieldOscalSspAuthorizationBoundaryDescri.description: A summary of the system's authorization boundary.

FieldOscalSspBaseType.title: Base Level (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability)
FieldOscalSspBaseType.description: The prescribed base (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

FieldOscalSspByComponentDescriptionType.title: Control Implementation Description
FieldOscalSspByComponentDescriptionType.description: An implementation statement that describes how a control or a control statement is implemented within the referenced system component.

FieldOscalSspByComponentExportDescriptio.title: Control Implementation Export Description
FieldOscalSspByComponentExportDescriptio.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of the control or control statement implementation that can be available to another system leveraging this system.

FieldOscalSspByComponentExportProvidedDe.title: Provided Control Implementation Description
FieldOscalSspByComponentExportProvidedDe.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of the control or control statement implementation that can be provided to another system leveraging this system.

FieldOscalSspByComponentExportResponsibi.title: Control Implementation Responsibility Description
FieldOscalSspByComponentExportResponsibi.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of the control or control statement implementation that a leveraging system must implement to satisfy the control provided by a leveraged system.

FieldOscalSspByComponentInheritedDescrip.title: Inherited Control Implementation Description
FieldOscalSspByComponentInheritedDescrip.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of a control or control statement implementation that a leveraging system is inheriting from a leveraged system.

FieldOscalSspByComponentSatisfiedDescrip.title: Satisfied Control Implementation Responsibility Description
FieldOscalSspByComponentSatisfiedDescrip.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of a control or control statement implementation that a leveraging system is implementing based on a requirement from a leveraged system.

FieldOscalSspControlImplementationDescri.title: Control Implementation Description
FieldOscalSspControlImplementationDescri.description: A statement describing important things to know about how this set of control satisfaction documentation is approached.

FieldOscalSspDataFlowDescriptionType.title: Data Flow Description
FieldOscalSspDataFlowDescriptionType.description: A summary of the system's data flow.

FieldOscalSspDateAuthorizedType.title: System Authorization Date
FieldOscalSspDateAuthorizedType.description: The date the system received its authorization.

FieldOscalSspDiagramCaptionType.title: Caption
FieldOscalSspDiagramCaptionType.description: A brief caption to annotate the diagram.

FieldOscalSspDiagramDescriptionType.title: Diagram Description
FieldOscalSspDiagramDescriptionType.description:
A summary of the diagram.

This description is intended to be used as alternate text to support compliance with requirements from [Section 508 of the United States Workforce Rehabilitation Act of 1973](https://www.section508.gov/manage/laws-and-policies).

FieldOscalSspNetworkArchitectureDescript.title: Network Architecture Description
FieldOscalSspNetworkArchitectureDescript.description: A summary of the system's network architecture.

FieldOscalSspSecurityImpactLevelSecurity.title: Security Objective: Availability
FieldOscalSspSecurityImpactLevelSecurity.description: A target-level of availability for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.

FieldOscalSspSecurityImpactLevelSecurity.title: Security Objective: Confidentiality
FieldOscalSspSecurityImpactLevelSecurity.description: A target-level of confidentiality for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.

FieldOscalSspSecurityImpactLevelSecurity.title: Security Objective: Integrity
FieldOscalSspSecurityImpactLevelSecurity.description: A target-level of integrity for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.

FieldOscalSspSelectedType.title: Selected Level (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability)
FieldOscalSspSelectedType.description: The selected (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

FieldOscalSspSystemCharacteristicsSecuri.title: Security Sensitivity Level
FieldOscalSspSystemCharacteristicsSecuri.description:
The overall information system sensitivity categorization, such as defined by [FIPS-199](https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.FIPS.199).

Often, organizations require the security sensitivity level to correspond with the highest confidentiality, integrity, or availability level identified by `security-impact-level`.

FieldOscalSspSystemCharacteristicsSystem.title: System Name - Short
FieldOscalSspSystemCharacteristicsSystem.description:
A short name for the system, such as an acronym, that is suitable for display in a data table or summary list.

Since `system-name-short` is optional, if the `system-name-short` is not provided, the `system-name` can be used as a substitute.

FieldOscalSspSystemCharacteristicsSystem.title: System Name - Full
FieldOscalSspSystemCharacteristicsSystem.description: The full name of the system.

FieldOscalSspSystemImplementationLeverag.title: party-uuid field
FieldOscalSspSystemImplementationLeverag.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to the `party` that manages the leveraged system.

FieldOscalSspSystemImplementationLeverag.title: title field
FieldOscalSspSystemImplementationLeverag.description: A human readable name for the leveraged authorization in the context of the system.

FieldOscalSspSystemInformationInformatio.title: Information Type Systematized Identifier
FieldOscalSspSystemInformationInformatio.description: A [human-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#human-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier qualified by the given identification `system` used, such as NIST SP 800-60. This identifier has [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope and can be used to reference this system elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). This id should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FieldOscalSspSystemInformationInformatio.title: Information Type Description
FieldOscalSspSystemInformationInformatio.description: A summary of how this information type is used within the system.

FieldOscalSspSystemInformationInformatio.title: title field
FieldOscalSspSystemInformationInformatio.description: A human readable name for the information type. This title should be meaningful within the context of the system.

FlagOscalControlCommonControlIdType.title: Control Identifier Reference
FlagOscalControlCommonControlIdType.description: A reference to a control with a corresponding `id` value. When referencing an externally defined `control`, the `Control Identifier Reference` must be used in the context of the external / imported OSCAL instance (e.g., uri-reference).

FlagOscalImplementationCommonImplementat.title: Implementation State
FlagOscalImplementationCommonImplementat.description: Identifies the implementation status of the control or control objective.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonInventoryIt.title: Component Universally Unique Identifier Reference
FlagOscalImplementationCommonInventoryIt.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to a `component` that is implemented as part of an inventory item.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonInventoryIt.title: Inventory Item Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalImplementationCommonInventoryIt.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this inventory item elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `inventory item` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonParamIdType.title: Parameter ID
FlagOscalImplementationCommonParamIdType.description: A [human-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#human-oriented) reference to a `parameter` within a control, who's catalog has been imported into the current implementation context.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonPortRangeEn.title: End
FlagOscalImplementationCommonPortRangeEn.description:
Indicates the ending port number in a port range for a transport layer protocol

Should be a number within a permitted range

FlagOscalImplementationCommonPortRangeSt.title: Start
FlagOscalImplementationCommonPortRangeSt.description:
Indicates the starting port number in a port range for a transport layer protocol

Should be a number within a permitted range

FlagOscalImplementationCommonProtocolNam.title: Protocol Name
FlagOscalImplementationCommonProtocolNam.description:
The common name of the protocol, which should be the appropriate "service name" from the [IANA Service Name and Transport Protocol Port Number Registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/service-names-port-numbers/service-names-port-numbers.xhtml).

The short name of the protocol (e.g., https).

FlagOscalImplementationCommonProtocolUui.title: Service Protocol Information Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalImplementationCommonProtocolUui.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this service protocol information elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `service protocol` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonStatementId.title: Control Statement Reference
FlagOscalImplementationCommonStatementId.description: A [human-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#human-oriented) identifier reference to a `control statement`.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemCompo.title: Component Type
FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemCompo.description: A category describing the purpose of the component.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemCompo.title: Component Identifier
FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemCompo.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this component elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `component` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemIdIde.title: Identification System Type
FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemIdIde.description:
Identifies the identification system from which the provided identifier was assigned.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemUserU.title: User Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalImplementationCommonSystemUserU.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this user class elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `system user` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalMetadataActionDateType.title: Action Occurrence Date
FlagOscalMetadataActionDateType.description: The date and time when the action occurred.

FlagOscalMetadataActionSystemType.title: Action Type System
FlagOscalMetadataActionSystemType.description:
Specifies the action type system used.

Provides a means to segment the value space for the `type`, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed `action`'s `type`. This allows the semantics associated with a given `type` to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.

An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.

FlagOscalMetadataActionTypeType.title: Action Type
FlagOscalMetadataActionTypeType.description: The type of action documented by the assembly, such as an approval.

FlagOscalMetadataActionUuidType.title: Action Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalMetadataActionUuidType.description: A unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined action elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceBase6.title: File Name
FlagOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceBase6.description: Name of the file before it was encoded as Base64 to be embedded in a `resource`. This is the name that will be assigned to the file when the file is decoded.

FlagOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceRlink.title: Hypertext Reference
FlagOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceRlink.description:
A resolvable URL pointing to the referenced resource.

This value may be either:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or

FlagOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceUuidT.title: Resource Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalMetadataBackMatterResourceUuidT.description: A unique identifier for a resource.

FlagOscalMetadataDocumentIdSchemeType.title: Document Identification Scheme
FlagOscalMetadataDocumentIdSchemeType.description:
Qualifies the kind of document identifier using a URI. If the scheme is not provided the value of the element will be interpreted as a string of characters.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

FlagOscalMetadataHashAlgorithmType.title: Hash algorithm
FlagOscalMetadataHashAlgorithmType.description:
The digest method by which a hash is derived.

Any other value used MUST be a value defined in the W3C [XML Security Algorithm Cross-Reference](https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlsec-algorithms/#digest-method-uris) Digest Methods (W3C, April 2013) or [RFC 6931 Section 2.1.5](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6931#section-2.1.5) New SHA Functions.

FlagOscalMetadataLinkHrefType.title: Hypertext Reference
FlagOscalMetadataLinkHrefType.description:
A resolvable URL reference to a resource.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to an OSCAL object by the objects identifier (e.g., id, uuid) in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)). The specific object type will differ based on the link relationship type.

FlagOscalMetadataLinkRelType.title: Link Relation Type
FlagOscalMetadataLinkRelType.description: Describes the type of relationship provided by the link's hypertext reference. This can be an indicator of the link's purpose.

FlagOscalMetadataLinkResourceFragmentTyp.title: Resource Fragment
FlagOscalMetadataLinkResourceFragmentTyp.description: In case where the `href` points to a `back-matter/resource`, this value will indicate the URI [fragment](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.5) to append to any `rlink` associated with the resource. This value MUST be [URI encoded](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.1).

FlagOscalMetadataMediaTypeType.title: Media Type
FlagOscalMetadataMediaTypeType.description:
A label that indicates the nature of a resource, as a data serialization or format.

The Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) [Media Types Registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml) defines a standardized set of media types, which may be used here.

The `application/oscal+xml`, `application/oscal+json` or `application/oscal+yaml` media types SHOULD be used when referencing OSCAL XML, JSON, or YAML resources respectively.

\*\*Note: There is no official media type for YAML at this time.\*\* OSCAL documents should specify `application/yaml` for general YAML content, or `application/oscal+yaml` for YAML-based OSCAL content. This approach aligns with use of a structured name suffix, per [RFC 6838 Section 4.2.8](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6838.html#section-4.2.8).

Some earlier OSCAL content incorporated the model into the media type. For example: `application/oscal.catalog+xml`. This practice SHOULD be avoided, since the OSCAL model can be detected by parsing the initial content of the referenced resource.

FlagOscalMetadataMetadataLocationUuidTyp.title: Location Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalMetadataMetadataLocationUuidTyp.description: A unique ID for the location, for reference.

FlagOscalMetadataMetadataPartyExternalId.title: External Identifier Schema
FlagOscalMetadataMetadataPartyExternalId.description:
Indicates the type of external identifier.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

FlagOscalMetadataMetadataPartyTypeType.title: Party Type
FlagOscalMetadataMetadataPartyTypeType.description: A category describing the kind of party the object describes.

FlagOscalMetadataMetadataPartyUuidType.title: Party Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalMetadataMetadataPartyUuidType.description: A unique identifier for the party.

FlagOscalMetadataMetadataRoleIdType.title: Role Identifier
FlagOscalMetadataMetadataRoleIdType.description: A unique identifier for the role.

FlagOscalMetadataPropertyClassType.title: Property Class
FlagOscalMetadataPropertyClassType.description:
A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's `name`.

This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same `name` and `ns`, or to group properties into categories.

A `class` can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a specific `class` value. It is available for grouping, but unlike `group` is not expected specifically to designate any group membership as such.

FlagOscalMetadataPropertyGroupType.title: Property Group
FlagOscalMetadataPropertyGroupType.description:
An identifier for relating distinct sets of properties.

Different sets of properties may relate to separate contexts. Declare a group on a property to associate it with one or more other properties in a given context.

FlagOscalMetadataPropertyNameType.title: Property Name
FlagOscalMetadataPropertyNameType.description: A textual label, within a namespace, that identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the property's containing object.

FlagOscalMetadataPropertyNsType.title: Property Namespace
FlagOscalMetadataPropertyNsType.description:
A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

When a `ns` is not provided, its value should be assumed to be `http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal` and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.

FlagOscalMetadataPropertyUuidType.title: Property Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalMetadataPropertyUuidType.description: A unique identifier for a property.

FlagOscalMetadataPropertyValueType.title: Property Value
FlagOscalMetadataPropertyValueType.description: Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.

FlagOscalMetadataResponsiblePartyRoleIdT.title: Responsible Role
FlagOscalMetadataResponsiblePartyRoleIdT.description: A reference to a `role` performed by a `party`.

FlagOscalMetadataResponsibleRoleRoleIdTy.title: Responsible Role ID
FlagOscalMetadataResponsibleRoleRoleIdTy.description: A [human-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#human-oriented) identifier reference to a `role` performed.

FlagOscalMetadataTelephoneNumberTypeType.title: type flag
FlagOscalMetadataTelephoneNumberTypeType.description: Indicates the type of phone number.

FlagOscalSspByComponentComponentUuidType.title: Component Universally Unique Identifier Reference
FlagOscalSspByComponentComponentUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to the `component` that is implemeting a given control.

FlagOscalSspByComponentExportProvidedUui.title: Provided Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalSspByComponentExportProvidedUui.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this provided entry elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `provided` entry can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalSspByComponentExportResponsibil.title: Responsibility Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalSspByComponentExportResponsibil.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this responsibility elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `responsibility` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalSspByComponentInheritedUuidType.title: Inherited Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalSspByComponentInheritedUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this inherited entry elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `inherited control implementation` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalSspByComponentSatisfiedUuidType.title: Satisfied Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalSspByComponentSatisfiedUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this satisfied control implementation entry elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `control implementation` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalSspByComponentUuidType.title: By-Component Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalSspByComponentUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this by-component entry elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `by-component` entry can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalSspDiagramUuidType.title: Diagram ID
FlagOscalSspDiagramUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this diagram elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `diagram` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

The locally defined *UUID* of the `control requirement` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). FlagOscalSspImportProfileHrefType.title: Profile Reference
FlagOscalSspImportProfileHrefType.description:
A resolvable URL reference to the profile or catalog to use as the system's control baseline.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to a `back-matter` resource in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)).

If the resource is an OSCAL profile, it is expected that a tool will resolve the profile according to the OSCAL [profile resolution specification](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/processing/profile-resolution/) to produce a resolved profile for use when processing the containing system security plan. This allows a system security plan processor to use the baseline as a catalog of controls.

While it is possible to reference a previously resolved OSCAL profile as a catalog, this practice is discouraged since the unresolved form of the profile communicates more information about selections and changes to the underlying catalog. Furthermore, the underlying catalog can be maintained separately from the profile, which also has maintenance advantages for distinct maintainers, ensuring that the best available information is produced through profile resolution.

FlagOscalSspProvidedUuidType.title: Provided UUID
FlagOscalSspProvidedUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to an inherited control implementation that a leveraging system is inheriting from a leveraged system.

FlagOscalSspResponsibilityUuidType.title: Responsibility UUID
FlagOscalSspResponsibilityUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to a control implementation that satisfies a responsibility imposed by a leveraged system.

FlagOscalSspStatementUuidType.title: Control Statement Reference Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalSspStatementUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this control statement elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The *UUID* of the `control statement` in the source OSCAL instance is sufficient to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance).

FlagOscalSspSystemImplementationLeverage.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope and can be used to reference this leveraged authorization elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `leveraged authorization` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

FlagOscalSspSystemInformationInformation.title: Information Type Identification System
FlagOscalSspSystemInformationInformation.description:
Specifies the information type identification system used.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

FlagOscalSspSystemSecurityPlanUuidType.title: System Security Plan Universally Unique Identifier
FlagOscalSspSystemSecurityPlanUuidType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this system security plan (SSP) elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ssp-identifiers). Base64Datatype.description: Binary data encoded using the Base 64 encoding algorithm as defined by RFC4648.

DateDatatype.description: A string representing a 24-hour period with an optional timezone.

DateTimeWithTimezoneDatatype.description: A string representing a point in time with a required timezone.

EmailAddressDatatype.description: An email address string formatted according to RFC 6531.

MarkupLineDatatype.description: A single line of Markdown content conformant to the Commonmark specification.

MarkupMultilineDatatype.description: A multiple lines of Markdown content conformant to the Commonmark specification.

NonNegativeIntegerDatatype.description: An integer value that is equal to or greater than 0.

StringDatatype.description:
A non-empty string with leading and trailing whitespace disallowed. Whitespace is: U+9, U+10, U+32 or [ 
	]+

TokenDatatype.description: A non-colonized name as defined by XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition. https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema11-2/#NCName.

URIDatatype.description: A universal resource identifier (URI) formatted according to RFC3986.

URIReferenceDatatype.description: A URI Reference, either a URI or a relative-reference, formatted according to section 4.1 of RFC3986.

UUIDDatatype.description: A type 4 ('random' or 'pseudorandom') or type 5 UUID per RFC 4122.
